question_details.title: In 2025, will the domestic content requirements become mandatory for obtaining the IRA's Production Tax Credits (45Y)?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-04-10 18:30:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/36487). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

On August 16, 2022, President Joe Biden signed into law the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which [expanded](https://www.epa.gov/green-power-markets/summary-inflation-reduction-act-provisions-related-renewable-energy) the production tax credits (PTC) for wind and geothermal-generated electricity to cover most renewable sources and extended them through 2032. The IRA also established a [domestic content bonus credit](https://www.akingump.com/en/insights/alerts/irs-updates-ptc-and-itc-domestic-content-bonus-guidance) of up to 10% for projects whose steel/iron and a specific percentage of their components were made in the US.

In the wake of the 2024 US elections, Republicans took control of both Houses of Congress and the White House, with President Donald Trump [having expressed interest](https://www.brookings.edu/articles/what-will-happen-to-the-inflation-reduction-act-under-a-republican-trifecta/#the-ira-under-the-incoming-republican-white-house-and-congress) in reducing IRA spending. At the time of this question, congressional Republicans were working on a budget reconciliation bill to possibly enact tax and spending changes to the federal budget (see the Tax Foundation's updated [Budget Reconciliation tracker](https://taxfoundation.org/research/all/federal/trump-tax-cuts-2025-budget-reconciliation/)).

It is important to note that in the House of Representatives, the Republicans hold a slim majority of 220 to 213. In March 2025, a group of 21 Republican representatives [sent a letter](https://www.eenews.net/articles/republicans-mull-thoughtful-phaseout-of-green-credits/) to House Ways and Means Chairman Jason Smith to urge him to phase out rather than eliminate the clean energy incentives of the IRA. House Speaker Mike Johnson [told reporters](https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/5167829-johnson-inflation-reduction-act-ira-climate-tax-infrastructure/), in regard to repealing clean energy tax credits among other policies, "It’ll be somewhere between a scalpel and a sledgehammer." It's important to note, too, that reconciliation bills do not always succeed. In July 2017, for example, Senator John McCain famously [cast](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/27/us/politics/senate-health-care-vote.html) a decisive No vote to a reconciliation bill that would have repealed parts of the Affordable Care Act.

**The battle over Affordable Care Act insurance subsidies**
The political standoff over the extension of enhanced Affordable Care Act (ACA) premium tax credits—federal subsidies that reduce monthly insurance premiums—has created significant uncertainty for millions of Americans ahead of the 2026 open enrollment period. These subsidies, expanded during the Biden administration through the 2021 American Rescue Plan and the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, made health insurance more affordable for middle-income individuals, leading to ACA enrollment rising from approximately 12 million in 2021 to about 24 million in 2025, according to KFF. The enhanced subsidies are set to expire in January 2026, and Republican lawmakers, including House Speaker Mike Johnson, argue Congress has until early 2026 to decide, calling the timeline 'an eternity.' However, Senate Democrats, led by Senator Patty Murray, warn that premium increases are already being locked in, with letters sent to families in October 2025, and are withholding support for a stopgap funding bill to force action. This has led to a partial government shutdown. State insurance regulators, including those from both Republican and Democratic-led states, have urged Congress to act earlier, warning that failing to extend the credits would result in hundreds of dollars in additional monthly premiums for millions and could make coverage unaffordable for many. The National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) emphasized in an August letter that without extension, the stability and affordability of state health insurance markets would be severely threatened. Even if subsidies are eventually extended, delays will cause irreversible harm: consumers may lose coverage due to sticker shock, distrust in the system, and the perception that government programs are unreliable. Experts like Jeanne Lambrew of The Century Foundation caution that while extending subsidies would help, the damage from delay is already done. Premiums for 2026 are projected to rise by a median of 18%, up from 7% in 2025, driven by the expiration of expanded subsidies, the cost of GLP-1 drugs, and a potential shift to less comprehensive catastrophic plans. Open enrollment begins November 1, 2025, in most states, with a December 15 deadline for coverage starting January 1, 2026. In Idaho, enrollment starts October 15. ACA plans, sold through federal and state exchanges, are offered by private insurers like UnitedHealth, Blue Cross, and Kaiser Permanente, and are categorized into metal tiers (bronze, silver, gold, platinum) based on cost-sharing. While premium tax credits reduce monthly premiums, cost-sharing reductions (CSRs) lower out-of-pocket expenses like deductibles and copayments for low-income enrollees. Studies show that even with tools to compare plans, many consumers fail to take full advantage of available financial aid. A 2019 Covered California experiment found that notifying consumers about enhanced silver plans via email and mail increased enrollment in better-value plans by 22% compared to no notification. Despite the ACA's success in reducing the uninsured rate from 15% in 2012 to 8% in 2023, research shows that coverage instability remains high, with about 12% of the insured losing coverage within two years—similar to pre-ACA levels—highlighting persistent 'health insurance uncertainty.'

The bill now goes to the President for signature. The bill contains amendments to the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 ('IRA') tax credits, including changes to the eligibility requirements for tax credits under sections 45 and 48. The bill accelerates the expiration of tax credits for wind and solar projects, requiring them to be placed in service by December 31, 2027. Additionally, the bill imposes Foreign Entity Ownership Control (FEOC) requirements on tax credits under sections 45Y, 48E, and 45X. The bill also codifies the definition of 'beginning of construction' for tax purposes and requires the Treasury Department to issue guidance on new threshold percentages for critical minerals by December 31, 2027. The imposition of FEOC rules introduces an additional layer of complexity to tax credit qualification.

**Renewable Energy Tax Credits in the Big, Beautiful Bill: Final Status**
The Big, Beautiful Bill (BBB) has been approved by Congress and is expected to be signed into law by President Trump on July 4, 2025. The bill includes several changes to the renewable energy tax credits enacted by the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 (IRA). Notably, the clean electricity tax credits (IRC §§ 45Y and 48E) will be unavailable for wind and solar projects placed in service after December 31, 2027, but a grandfather rule will preserve eligibility for projects that start construction before the date that is 12 months following enactment of the Bill. The prohibition on using imported nuclear fuel under IRC § 45U has been removed, and the new excise tax applicable to wind and solar projects that violate the material assistance rules has been excluded from the final version of the BBB. The clean fuel production credit under IRC § 45Z has been extended through the end of 2029, and the credit will only be available for fuel produced from feedstocks produced in the United States, Mexico, and Canada. The value of the IRC § 45Z credit has been capped at $1.00 per gallon, except in the case of fuel produced from animal manure. The clean hydrogen production credit under IRC § 45V will be sunsetted for hydrogen projects that have not yet commenced by December 31, 2027.

**Inflation Reduction Act Would Significantly Expand Federal Income Tax Benefits for Green Technology Industry**
The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 expands federal income‑tax benefits for green‑technology projects.  It extends the existing Section 45 PTC and Section 48 ITC for wind and solar facilities, adds the PTC to new solar projects, and removes sunset provisions for facilities placed in service after 2021.  The Act introduces a new Section 45Y clean‑electricity production credit (CEPTC) and a Section 48D clean‑electricity investment credit (CEITC) that apply to any renewable or energy‑storage facility that begins construction after 2025, with rates tied to a 0 % greenhouse‑gas‑emissions standard.  Energy‑storage facilities gain an election out of the public‑utility property limitation and are treated as five‑year property under MACRS.  The Act also expands the ITC/PTC to energy‑storage, biogas, microgrid controller equipment, and provides a separate PTC for electricity used to produce clean hydrogen under Section 45V.  Wage‑and‑apprenticeship standards can trigger an 80 % credit haircut, while meeting domestic‑content or energy‑community standards can add a 10 % (or 20 % for low‑income communities) credit enhancement.  The Section 45Q carbon‑capture credit is extended to facilities beginning construction before 2033, with a higher rate for direct‑air‑capture.  Fuel‑production credits are extended through 2024 and a new Section 45Z clean‑fuel credit is introduced for 2025‑2027.  The dormant Section 48C investment credit is revived for advanced‑energy production and manufacturing, with a $10 billion ceiling.  The Act creates refundable credits for tax‑exempt entities, allows sale of refundable credits, and changes carry‑over rules to a 3‑year carryback and 22‑year carryforward.  These provisions aim to streamline compliance, incentivize domestic content, and broaden financing options for green projects.
